title: A modified gastric tube reconstruction following laparoscopic proximal gastrectomy for early adenocarcinoma in the upper third stomach and esophagogastric junction: short-term surgical outcomes.
abstract: Proximal gastrectomy with conventional esophagogastrostomy is frequently associated with postoperative complications including significant reflux esophagitis. This study evaluates a modified reconstruction technique combining gastric tube formation with overlap anastomosis and partial fundoplication. Between January 2021 and January 2024, 29 consecutive patients diagnosed with early-stage proximal gastric cancer underwent laparoscopic proximal gastrectomy with our novel reconstruction method. The surgical protocol included creation of a gastric tube conduit, overlap esophagogastric anastomosis, and partial fundoplication procedure. Perioperative outcomes and postoperative follow-up data were prospectively collected. The cohort demonstrated a mean operative time of 239 ± 50minutes (mean ± SD) and median estimated blood loss of 50mL (IQR: 20-150mL). Lymph node dissection yielded a median count of 25 nodes (range: 9-66). Postoperative complications included one case (3.4%) of anastomotic leakage requiring conservative management. Mild reflux symptoms (heartburn) were transiently observed in two patients (6.9%), both resolving with short-term proton pump inhibitor therapy. Endoscopic evaluation at 3-month follow-up revealed grade A or grade B reflux esophagitis (Los Angeles classification) in two patients (6.9%). Nutritional parameters (serum albumin and total protein levels) showed expected postoperative declines during the initial 3-month period, followed by progressive recovery to preoperative baseline values by 6 months postoperatively (p<0.05 for longitudinal comparison). Our preliminary findings suggest that gastric tube reconstruction with overlap anastomosis and partial fundoplication represents a technically feasible and safe approach for proximal gastrectomy, demonstrating acceptable short-term functional outcomes with mitigated reflux complications.
